qa_list.question: What are attractors in a dynamical system related to vocal fold behaviors?,answer: Attractors in a dynamical system related to vocal fold behaviors reveal the periodic motion of the flow in phase space.
qa_list.ref_chunk: variables (or their starting point). To study vocal fold behaviors, we are particularly interested in those attractors revealing the periodic motion of the ﬂow in phase space. Such attractors include the limit cycle or the limit torus, which are isolated periodic or toroidal orbits, respectively. Some attractor sets have a fractal structure resultant from a chaotic state of the dynamical system [20,54], and are called strange attractors. Figure A1. Illustration of different attractors in a dynamical system. Appendix F.4. Chaos and Exponential Divergence of Phase Space Trajectories Chaos is a characteristic state of a nonlinear dynamical system. There are different deﬁnitions of chaos. A simple one is as follows: Deﬁnition A5 (Chaos). Equip a distance metric d on the phase space M. Then C ∈ M is referred to as a chaotic set of Φ if, for any x, y ∈ C, x (cid:54)= y, we have n→∞ inf d(Φn(x), Φn(y)) = 0 lim n→∞ sup d(Φn(x), Φn(y)) > 0 lim Thus, by deﬁnition, chaos is a state characterized by extreme sensitivity to initial conditions (trajectories starting from any two arbitrarily close initial conditions diverge exponentially). The Lypunov exponent is used to quantify this divergence. It also measures the measures the sensitivity of the evolution of the dynamical system to initial conditions. 36 of 39 (A152) (A153) Entropy 2023, 25, 1039 Appendix F.5. Stability Attractor sets (of all types) also characterize the stability of dynamical systems. Deﬁnition A6 (Stability). A compact Φ-invariant subset A = Φ(A) ⊆ M is called a Lyapunov stable attraction set if 1. 2. It has an open basin of attraction B(A); The Lyapunov stability condition is satisﬁed: every neighborhood U of A contains a smaller neighborhood V such that every iterative forward image Φn(V) is contained in U. Appendix F.6. Poincaré Map and Poincaré Section To study the trajectory (or orbit) structure of dynamical systems, we use the Poincaré map or Poincaré section. Deﬁnition A7 (Poincaré map [53]). For an n-dimensional phase space with a periodic orbit γx, a Poincaré section S is an (n − 1)-dimensional section (hyper-plane) that is transverse to γx. Given an open, connected neighborhood U ⊆ S of x, the Poincaré map on Poincaré section S is a map P : U → S, x (cid:55)→ Φx(ts) where ts is the time between the two intersections, satisfying 1. 2. P(U) is a neighborhood of x and P : U → P(U) is a diffeomorphism; For every point x in U, the positive semi-orbit of x intersects S for the ﬁrst time at P(x). Appendix F.7. Bifurcation Since the ﬂow of a dynamical system in its phase space is a function of its parameters, the topological structure of the trajectories (including attractor sets) in phase space changes as the parameters change. To see how the topological structure changes with system parameters, we study the bifurcation map of the system. Deﬁnition A8 (Bifurcation). A bifurcation occurs when a small smooth change in a system parameter value causes an abrupt change in the topological structure of the trajectory in phase space. A bifurcation diagram is a visualization of the system’s parameter space showing the number and behavior of attractor sets for each parameter conﬁguration. At a bifurcation point, the system stability may change as the topological structure splits or merges, such as the periodic doubling or halving of a limit cycle. References 1. 2. 3. 4. Cveticanin, L. Then C ∈ M is referred to as a chaotic set of Φ if, for any x, y ∈ C, x (cid:54)= y, we have n→∞ inf d(Φn(x), Φn(y)) = 0 lim n→∞ sup d(Φn(x), Φn(y)) > 0 lim Thus, by deﬁnition, chaos is a state characterized by extreme sensitivity to initial conditions (trajectories starting from any two arbitrarily close initial conditions diverge exponentially). The Lypunov exponent is used to quantify this divergence. It also measures the measures the sensitivity of the evolution of the dynamical system to initial conditions. 36 of 39 (A152) (A153) Entropy 2023, 25, 1039 Appendix F.5. Stability Attractor sets (of all types) also characterize the stability of dynamical systems. Deﬁnition A6 (Stability). A compact Φ-invariant subset A = Φ(A) ⊆ M is called a Lyapunov stable attraction set if 1. 2. It has an open basin of attraction B(A); The Lyapunov stability condition is satisﬁed: every neighborhood U of A contains a smaller neighborhood V such that every iterative forward image Φn(V) is contained in U. Appendix F.6. Poincaré Map and Poincaré Section To study the trajectory (or orbit) structure of dynamical systems, we use the Poincaré map or Poincaré section. Deﬁnition A7 (Poincaré map [53]). For an n-dimensional phase space with a periodic orbit γx, a Poincaré section S is an (n − 1)-dimensional section (hyper-plane) that is transverse to γx. Given an open, connected neighborhood U ⊆ S of x, the Poincaré map on Poincaré section S is a map P : U → S, x (cid:55)→ Φx(ts) where ts is the time between the two intersections, satisfying 1. 2. P(U) is a neighborhood of x and P : U → P(U) is a diffeomorphism; For every point x in U, the positive semi-orbit of x intersects S for the ﬁrst time at P(x). Appendix F.7. Bifurcation Since the ﬂow of a dynamical system in its phase space is a function of its parameters, the topological structure of the trajectories (including attractor sets) in phase space changes as the parameters change. To see how the topological structure changes with system parameters, we study the bifurcation map of the system. Deﬁnition A8 (Bifurcation). A bifurcation occurs when a small smooth change in a system parameter value causes an abrupt change in the topological structure of the trajectory in phase space. A bifurcation diagram is a visualization of the system’s parameter space showing the number and behavior of attractor sets for each parameter conﬁguration. At a bifurcation point, the system stability may change as the topological structure splits or merges, such as the periodic doubling or halving of a limit cycle. References 1. 2. 3. 4. Cveticanin, L. qa_list.question: How does the topological structure of trajectories change in a dynamical system with bifurcation?,answer: The topological structure of trajectories changes as the parameters change, leading to changes in the attractor sets in phase space.
